proof:
Proof. We consider the degree on each vertex $v$. Firstly, there is at most one value of $i$ for which $v$ is incident to some edge in $R_i$. After all, by Lemma 3.5, if an edge in $R_i$ is incident to $v$, then $v \notin Q_{i-1}$ and $v$ is not in $G_{\text{Base}}(i)$ nor any subsequent graphs. For this value of $i$, $\Delta(R_i) \le \frac{\Delta}{l}$. Furthermore, $\Delta(H_j) \le \frac{2\Delta}{l}$ for all $j \in [k]$ by Lemma 3.4. Thus, $\text{deg}(v)$ cannot exceed $\frac{\Delta}{l}$ in $R_i$ nor $\frac{2\Delta}{l}$ in $H_j$ for any $j \in [k]$.
Since $G_{\text{input}} = (\cup_{i=1}^k H_i) \cup (\cup_{i=1}^k R_i)$, the degree of $v$ in $G_{\text{input}}$ is the sum of its degree in each of these graphs. In particular, the degree of $v$ is $\le k \cdot \frac{2\Delta}{l} + \frac{\Delta}{l} \le \frac{4 \ln(n) \cdot \Delta}{l} + \frac{\Delta}{l} < \frac{\Delta}{2} + \frac{\Delta}{2} = \Delta$. The last is true by $l \ge 8 \ln n$. The second last inequality is true by $k = [\ln(n)] + 1$ and $n > \eta$.
